body: it already shows types at hover.
Definitely a good first step, but I can imagine a proper TypeScript example would improve the developer experience.
Any thoughts on how we could automate this? It'd be a neat feature, but needing to maintain both variants would be prohibitive, I think

wouldn't it be better to just anotate it dirrectly in one of these two styles of typing and just convert it to second one, and if I know tsc can do that. Also there are libs for it, see: https://www.npmjs.com/package/ts-to-jsdoc
Sure, if this also works with type imports?

ts-to-jsdoc doesn't appear to work. I think we'd need to create our own special syntax as in https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/issues/4452#issuecomment-1085444682, which I can imagine proving quite costly over time

issue.title: TypeScript load function example

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: SvelteKit cannot be used by a small number of people, quality of life improvements, etc.

issue.title: TypeScript example for params file in Routing docs

body:
> For me, a person that knows both syntaxes well, this might be a small problem.

To give some input from a beginner in TypeScript and SvelteKit: It is immensely difficult to both, learn TypeScript and SvelteKit, when also having to translate the examples from JavaScript and JSDoc (which is something I haven't heard before). Having all examples in the SK docs available in TypeScript would be _immensely_ helpful!

Copying some comments Rich made on Discord here to better preserve them:

It absolutely needs to be auto-generated, yes. The big challenge is that we ideally want your settings to be persisted (rather than the page loading then there being a big layout shift while it switches from JS mode to TS mode), which implies we can't use prerendering. But we need prerendering, because the docs are driven by markdown files, and we don't have access to those files in the deployed app, just the code.

In short, this would be a huge undertaking that will involve a complete rethink of how our docs are created

It's an interesting case  we still want to avoid recomputing the HTML for every request. JS/TS and light/dark modes are examples of a situation where you want to prerender multiple options and choose between them on the edge. it's something that kit doesn't support, but something we maybe should support

issue.title: [docs] add typescript code snippets
issue.body:
...by adding a toggle that shows snippets either in TS or JS code. The toggle is implemented using CSS and a blocking script which adds a class to the html tag, which makes the correct one of the two snippets appear. The TS versions are generated from the JS versions through a transformation step.
Closes #4452

Marked as draft because ~`$app/X` imports are not recognized in the TS version for some reason; and~ I don't know where to place the toggle. It's at the top of the navigation sidebar for testing, but that obviously isn't a good solution. I see basically two options:
1. Some fixed place on the page so you toggle JS/TS globally
2. Each snippet that has a TS version gets some toggle icon on the top right. It would also toggle all other snippets to TS so you don't have to do it for each snippet. One way to achieve this with the given setup would be to put both the JS and generated TS version into one code snippet, separating them through some special comment. Then when marked invokes the `code` method we separate them again, transform them independently and then wrap them inside some block which would have the toggle visible if JavaScript is enabled in the browser.

### Please don't delete this checklist! Before submitting the PR, please make sure you do the following:
- [ ] It's really useful if your PR references an issue where it is discussed ahead of time. In many cases, features are absent for a reason. For large changes, please create an RFC: https://github.com/sveltejs/rfcs
- [x] This message body should clearly illustrate what problems it solves.
- [ ] Ideally, include a test that fails without this PR but passes with it.

### Tests
- [ ] Run the tests with `pnpm test` and lint the project with `pnpm lint` and `pnpm check`

### Changesets
- [ ] If your PR makes a change that should be noted in one or more packages' changelogs, generate a changeset by running `pnpm changeset` and following the prompts. All changesets should be `patch` until SvelteKit 1.0
